addressleaf.section:
To my loving frend M
r
Thomas Bodeley Esquier./

from my L. Tresurer the 25 of July
1591
.

page.lettertext:
fol.184r
Belgia 1591 25 July To M
r
Bodly
Belgia: 1591: July.
S
r
. I have imparted unto hir
Ma
tie
sondrie of yo
r
l
re
s lately
written whereof the last is the xvij
th
of this moneth: wheareuppon
hir Ma
tie
hath presentlie written a letter to the
Counte Maurice
both
to showe hir gladnes for the victorie, and politicquelie to move a staie
of the puttinge the great Prisoners to libertie untill the sommer be past
as by the Copie of the letter hearewith sent, yowe shall better understand
w
ch
when yowe have perused yowe maie deliver to the Counte w
th
hir Ma
ties
most hartie Commendac
o
ns: and w
th
other Complement
to
expresse hir Ma
ties
great joie that she hath for the publicque victorie,
and of hir perticuler gladnes for the Countes perticuler prosperitie in
thes his Actions, greatlie to his honno
r
, and to the love of the
Cuntrie. And thowgh at this time the Contentes of hir Ma
ties
letters be
generallie to staie the deliverie of prisoners that be of vallewe for
s
rvice: yet she is vearie desirous, that theare be one fitt man
obtained, whose vallewe might redeme
M
r
Winter
that is in the
Castell of
Anwerpe
wheare he hath been of longe time vearye cru-
ellie used by
Mondragon,
and yet I cannot wholie defend him bicawse
he sowght to escape: and yet since that time theie have pretended
to kepe him streighte, thearebie to provoke the Q. to deliver
Don Pedro
de Valdes
, wheareunto hir Ma
tie
will in noe wise assent: And
therefore I see noe readie waie for Winter to be delivered but by
exchange of sum prisoners wheareof if one such cowld be choosen
[.] as weare of vallewe for wealthe, and not for martiall Action
yowe showld doe the Gentleman great pleisure: and to this ende
the Bearer heareof being a
s
rvant of M
r
Winters cometh unto yo
u
to sollicite this suite for his M
r
, to whome I praie yowe showe
all the favor yowe can./ Hir Ma
tie
hath receved letters from
the
Counsell of State
, vearie bitterlie written against
S
r
Edward
Norris
, and as yt semeth yo
r
self doth concerne the cawse of
theire writinge against him to be trewe: But for mine owne
part havinge receved from him soe often times a Justifica
o
n
of himself in all thos thinges whearew
th
he is charged, and
lastlie perceiving that he hath sent a Commissarie of the
towne to the
States
w
th
his letters in awnsweare of theire
Complaintes: I have great Cawse to hope that he will be
fownd noethinge soe fawltie as he hath been made to appeare
fol.184v
Belgia: 1591: July.
to yowe and the States: And this I knowe for a trewthe
that neither theie of
Holland
& spetiallie of
Zeland
doe like
to have that towne of
Ostend,
or anie thinge in
Flanders
to
prosper, but howe proffitable yt is for yt to be mainteined
for the annoyance of the Ennemie is easelie to be judged, and
in trewthe if the States would have as good a minde to recover
the townes of Flanders as theie have to increase theire bowndes
in
Gelderland,
and the Confines of Holland, the Ennemie showld
receive more losse by the [ruining] of one towne in Flanders [and]
the States, than by anie three in Gelderland./
Theare is a letter w
ch
I nowe send yowe w
ch
hath laine long
by mee half forgotten directed to yowe for this matter of S
r
Edward Norris, whearebie yowe are to offer to the States that
hir Ma
tie
will well allowe to have S
r
Edward Norris Action
duelie examined, by sending sum Commissarye of theire owne &
to joine
M
r
Guilpin
w
th
him, w
ch
if he cannot be staied
I thinke sum Capteine might be named from
Flusshinge
or
Berghen
that weare not knowen ill affected to S
r
Edward
Norris to joine w
th
the States Commissary: And if yowe doe
find the States not satisfied w
th
the sending of the Commissary
from Ostend and his awnsweare, then I praie yo
u
further
that Course as yt is conteined in the letter./
I wishe to have had sum plat or discription of the grownd
of the late fight betwixt
Arnham
&
Newmegen,
and soe I
praie yowe heareafter uppon anie occasion of fight
in plac
to joine w
th
yo
r
letter sum discripc
o
ns of the places, and
formes of the fight
, for the better understanding of the same, for
manie times report
are made as this sommer hath been of many
sconces neare
Groninghen,
but in the platt
of the Cuntries such
places are not expresed or mentioned./ I would also at
such like times [wee] would advertise us, whoe be the leaders &
Capteines of the States Armies, and what officers they usuallye
have in the Conductinge of theire Armies./ And wheare of late
yt appeareth theare hath been sum motion made to have the
Almaigne Armie to cum into that Cuntrie, Althowgh I know
fol.185r
Belgia: 1591. July.
it would be to great purpose for thos partes theare, yet I
thinke the
Frenche K
. will not allowe thereof, consideringe the
delaie of their comminge into
France
maie prove dangerous to
him, by reason of the comminge into France owt of
Italie
of the
Popes
forces, under the Conduct of the Popes nephewe, and of
other great forces to be Conducted by the
D. of Savoye
, whoe is cum
owt of
Spaigne
w
th
plentie of monie, to paie as manie soldiers
as he can levie./ Fr
o
Grenwych.
e 25 of Julij
1591
I pray yow let
S
r Fr
a
cis vere
, know
t
I have receaved his
late l
re
s mak
y
g
ticular meti
o
of
e victory ag
ey
st
the Italli
o
Cavallery. for w
c
I thanck h
y
most hartely
wishyng
t
he wold not wryte so hastely w
t
a ru
n
ing
hand, for though I can decipher the same, yet I wold
offre the same to be redd by
e Q. Ma
ty
, who [new]
only my read
y
g or report, the difficulte resteth
o
ly
in iij or iiij l
re
s, as his dooble v and his
[.]
such lyke. I hope he will accept this my frendl y
playnes w
t
h
y
./
Your assured loving frend William Burghley
